cluster_relations.rel_desc: The Rhodopis Cinderella tale is identified as the earliest known version of the Cinderella story.

qualifiers.TemporalQualifier: ancient Greece; earlier than later cultural forms
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: ComparativeContext: among various cultural forms told for centuries

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The Cinderella fairytale’s most familiar modern form is identified with Perrault's 1697 version.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: FamiliarityStatus: most people are familiar with this version

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject narrative is a version or variant of the object narrative, distinguished by period, culture, or other features.
args.justification: The Rhodopis Cinderella tale is described as the earliest known version of the broader Cinderella fairytale; this fits a generic versioning predicate from specific variant (subject) to overarching narrative (object). Temporal qualifiers already capture the 'earliest known' aspect, so the canonical predicate can remain general.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject narrative has the object as one of its specific versions or variants.
args.justification: Here the subject is the general Cinderella fairytale and the object is Perrault's specific version; this is the inverse direction of a versioning relation, so a predicate from whole work to specific version ('has_version') is appropriate, while keeping the Rhodopis relation as 'is_version_of'.

Both relations concern different textual or narrative versions of the Cinderella story (variant-to-work and work-to-variant). Grouping them under a shared class for versioning among narratives captures their common semantics despite inverse direction.

Narrative versions represent alternate realizations of essentially the same identity (the Cinderella story) rather than composition, causality, or mere association; versioning is best treated as an identity/variant relationship.
